From mklishin at gopivotal.com  Thu Sep 12 10:53:10 2013
From: mklishin at gopivotal.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 10:53:10 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Strange behaviour of RabbitMQ or client when
	network problems occurs
In-Reply-To: <1378979267460-29553.post@n5.nabble.com>
References: <1378979267460-29553.post@n5.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <934A8980-E88B-42F5-9F4D-5009B1756127@rabbitmq.com>

Haster:

> And in result we get 11 duplicated messages and only to times we were in
> point (2), where
> we couldn't send ack.
> I can't understand where from 9 duplicated messages come? 

So, are you getting 11 or 9 redeliveries?

All unacknowledged messages will be requeued when the channel closes.
Looks like your way of creating network interference causes TCP connection
to be closed, which in turn makes RabbitMQ consider all your channels closed.

With prefetch = 20, if 9 messages were acked and then connection terminated,
you will get exactly 11 redeliveries after you reconnect and re-register your consumer(s).

MK

From simon at rabbitmq.com  Thu Sep 12 10:54:05 2013
From: simon at rabbitmq.com (Simon MacMullen)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 10:54:05 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] How to detect if RMQ service is running a
 node (clustered) ?
In-Reply-To: <1378732523165-29468.post@n5.nabble.com>
References: <1378720814691-29459.post@n5.nabble.com>
	<1378731556340-29466.post@n5.nabble.com>
	<522DC6FB.8090405@rabbitmq.com>
	<1378732523165-29468.post@n5.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <52318F3D.7080601@rabbitmq.com>

On 09/09/13 14:15, ding wrote:
> Hi Simon,
>
>>> Those are the standard messages logged when a RabbitMQ server is shut
> down. What do you think is the issue here?
>
> One node has been  taken out of the cluster (automatically) since those
> messages appeared in the log file. Why RMQ got shutdown ? any idea ?

The message "Halting Erlang VM" will only ever be logged in response to 
"rabbitmqctl stop" (or something that invokes that like 
"/etc/init.d/rabbitmq-server stop"), or when requesting to stop the 
Windows service. It is not something that will be logged when the Erlang 
VM shuts down for any other reason.

So something outside of RabbitMQ told it to shut down.

Cheers, Simon

-- 
Simon MacMullen
RabbitMQ, Pivotal

From matthias at rabbitmq.com  Thu Sep 12 11:13:58 2013

Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] RabbitMQ 'hang' when trying to access HA

Andrew,

On 11/09/13 15:56, Andrew Rendell wrote:
> Last week, during a very important test, under very low load conditions,
> suddenly, two queues ?hung?.

Was there anything unusual in the logs?

> What we are hoping is that somebody could give us any indication of what
> could cause this issue. In an ideal world, somebody would report that
> this is a known issue with 2.7.1 and that the issue is resolved at a
> later release.

"queues hang" is not the signature of any bug we've fixed since 2.7.1. 
However, it is unlikely that you have stumbled on a new problem. Odds 
are that whatever causes the hang is no longer present in the most 
recent rabbit releases.

Matthias.

Thanks for your posts.

>>Any activity on a connection counts for a heart beat. Can you post a
snippet of code 
>>that creates connection factory and a connection? 

Sure, 
C#:
var connectionFactory = new ConnectionFactory { Uri =
"amqp://guest:guest at 10.112.1.250:5672/%2F" };
var conn = connectionFactory.CreateConnection();
var channel = conn.CreateModel();

... // << Breakpoint here, wait 30 mins - connection is dropped

Java:
public static void main(String[] args) {
    try {
        ConnectionFactory connectionFactory = new ConnectionFactory();
       
connectionFactory.setUri("amqp://guest:guest at 10.112.1.250:5672/%2F");

        Connection connection = connectionFactory.newConnection();
        Channel channel = connection.createChannel();

        String k = "gfdgdgdf"; // << Breakpoint here, wait 30 mins -
connection is dropped
    } catch (Exception e){
        logger.warn(e);
    }
    System.exit(0);
}

If I set up a requestedHeartbeat, for example, 10, after 10 seconds
connection is dropped. This is Windows machine on both clients.
Also I'm using also rabbitmq-river for elasticsearch. Client is 3.1.1 there.
It runs from Ubuntu machine and connection idle for 2 days and don't
dropped.

Source there:
https://github.com/elasticsearch/elasticsearch-river-rabbitmq/blob/master/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/river/rabbitmq/RabbitmqRiver.java

Thanks

From mklishin at gopivotal.com  Thu Sep 12 11:20:29 2013
From: mklishin at gopivotal.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 11:20:29 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Suddenly dropping all conns?
In-Reply-To: <1378980857047-29557.post@n5.nabble.com>
References: <1377272675467-29050.post@n5.nabble.com>
	<B389F8D3-44FE-4FC4-8E38-73223774FE60@gopivotal.com>
	<1377499585998-29076.post@n5.nabble.com>
	<521B175A.3070700@rabbitmq.com>
	<1377512500727-29082.post@n5.nabble.com>
	<521B2D33.7090605@rabbitmq.com>
	<1378926320550-29537.post@n5.nabble.com>

	<1378980857047-29557.post@n5.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <8E9CC7FD-CD57-401B-A7F2-9BBCC86E84CE@rabbitmq.com>

ku3ia:

> var connectionFactory = new ConnectionFactory { Uri =
> "amqp://guest:guest at 10.112.1.250:5672/%2F" };

Please set RequestedHeartbeat here.

> var conn = connectionFactory.CreateConnection();

Our hypothesis is that when you breakpoint a C# client, the entire VM is paused
and so heartbeat sender does not send anything out. With ElasticSearch RabbitMQ
river, no breakpoints are involved, so heartbeat sender is able to do its job.

MK

From Andrew.Rendell at vocalink.com  Thu Sep 12 11:41:25 2013
From: Andrew.Rendell at vocalink.com (Andrew Rendell)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 11:41:25 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] RabbitMQ 'hang' when trying to access HA
 queues
In-Reply-To: <523193E6.9020200@rabbitmq.com>
References: <8D76E9325134094DA4CFA89A132A4D640270D511BF@SPR3V9.office.local> 
	<523193E6.9020200@rabbitmq.com>
Message-ID: <8D76E9325134094DA4CFA89A132A4D640270D511EF@SPR3V9.office.local>

Hi,

You asked:

> Was there anything unusual in the logs?

No. This was what was most disconcerting about this issue. We have done many many hours of testing under very high loads with multiple failure scenarios and whenever there has been an issue there has always been something in the log files which gave some indication of the problem. In this case the only entries we could see in the log files were the aborted connection reports from rabbitmqctl (I assume when it was cancelled by the operator).

>"queues hang" is not the signature of any bug we've fixed since 2.7.1. 
> However, it is unlikely that you have stumbled on a new problem. Odds are that whatever causes the hang is no longer present in the most recent rabbit releases.

It's a shame that this issue was not explicitly resolved since 2.7.1 as it would have eased the minds of the various parties involved in the investigation. Would it be correct to say that since 2.7.1 there has been major rewrites of the HA queue implementation and given the strong advice for users to upgrade to 2.8 and beyond, it is probable there were very few people using 2.7.1 in HA mode so a defect might have remain undiscovered? I appreciate this sort of question is impossible to answer without a significant amount of conjecture so any answer would be based on 'gut feeling'. 

Regards, Andrew.

-----Original Message-----

> what could cause this issue. In an ideal world, somebody would report

"queues hang" is not the signature of any bug we've fixed since 2.7.1. 
However, it is unlikely that you have stumbled on a new problem. Odds are that whatever causes the hang is no longer present in the most recent rabbit releases.

Matthias.

Andrew,

On 12/09/13 11:41, Andrew Rendell wrote:
>> Was there anything unusual in the logs?
>
> No. This was what was most disconcerting about this issue.

Hmm. Quite.

> Would it be correct to say that since 2.7.1 there has been major
> rewrites of the HA queue implementation

It's not been rewritten as such, but has undergone substantial change
and improvement. There have been nearly 40 bug fixes to mirrored queues
since 2.7.1.

> it is probable there were very few people using 2.7.1 in HA mode

...for a considerable length of time and/or with extensive testing...

> so a defect might have remain undiscovered?

Correct.

Matthias.

From tim at rabbitmq.com  Thu Sep 12 12:57:56 2013
From: tim at rabbitmq.com (Tim Watson)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 12:57:56 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] is there any way to communicate back from
	the subscriber to producer in the rabbit mq when
	exange_type=fanout..
In-Reply-To: <96368392-38f2-47f4-8d07-b776699f2662@googlegroups.com>
References: <96368392-38f2-47f4-8d07-b776699f2662@googlegroups.com>
Message-ID: <5A0C4C39-99F1-4017-B347-A763A03A24A0@rabbitmq.com>

On 12 Sep 2013, at 12:47, rajjs wrote:
> is there any way to communicate or the send the response message  back from the subscriber to producer in the rabbit mq when exange_type=fanout..

As per http://www.rabbitmq.com/tutorials/tutorial-six-python.html:

"The AMQP protocol predefines a set of 14 properties that go with a message. Most of the properties are rarely used, with the exception of the following:

delivery_mode: Marks a message as persistent (with a value of 2) or transient (any other value). You may remember this property from the second tutorial.
content_type: Used to describe the mime-type of the encoding. For example for the often used JSON encoding it is a good practice to set this property to: application/json.
reply_to: Commonly used to name a callback queue."

So you can specify the name of a reply queue in the basic.properties attached to a message, and use that to send a reply if necessary.

Tim

From matthias at rabbitmq.com  Thu Sep 12 13:26:53 2013
From: matthias at rabbitmq.com (Matthias Radestock)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 13:26:53 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Strange behaviour of RabbitMQ or client when
 network problems occurs
In-Reply-To: <1378987905364-29570.post@n5.nabble.com>
References: <1378979267460-29553.post@n5.nabble.com>
	<934A8980-E88B-42F5-9F4D-5009B1756127@rabbitmq.com>
	<1378986271558-29563.post@n5.nabble.com>
	<5231AA5E.1070209@rabbitmq.com>
	<1378987297559-29568.post@n5.nabble.com>
	<5231ADF5.4090508@rabbitmq.com>
	<1378987905364-29570.post@n5.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <5231B30D.1060705@rabbitmq.com>

On 12/09/13 13:11, Haster wrote:
> so I can't guarantee that if I send basic_ack I won't send it again?

There's no 'ack' for an 'ack', so indeed you generally cannot guarantee 
that the server has seen an ack. There are ways around that, e.g. you 
could put the channel in transactional mode, in which case the commit-ok 
response serves an 'ack for the ack'. But that seriously impacts 
performance and doesn't address the broader issue of dealing with 
duplicates (which are unavoidable).

> And duplicated messages I have to throw out on application level?

Yes. I'm assuming you've read http://www.rabbitmq.com/reliability.html

Matthias.

Hi rabbitmq gurus

  In our environment, there is a probability that 
  a portion of our outside consumers  will "come and go away after a
while" ...

  Except for the rabbitmq-management plugin, there is no rabbitmqctl
command to
  delete a queue... is this right !?

  So the only way to delete an unwanted queue will be to code something 
  using the administrator user that will delete a queue using its
name... is that right !? 
  It is possible using PIKA ?
  

		Michel Grenier
		(514) 421-7204



-----Original Message-----
From: Grenier,Michel [CMC] 
Sent: 11 September, 2013 11:03
To: 'Discussions about RabbitMQ'
Subject: RE: [rabbitmq-discuss] losing messages

More details about message leaking

My publishers all open one connection, uses 1 channel and declare and
feed the same exchange (exchange with auto-delete = true)

When I start the publishers the exchange is created and receives
(publish-in) messages.

Than running my consumer :
it opens one connection, uses 1 channel, creates a queue
(auto-delete=true) and declare the same exchange (auto-delete=true)  and
bind the exchange  to its queue everything runs smoothly.

When I stop my consumer the exchange is deleted in the rabbitmq server
(rabbitmq-management shows that)
even if the publishers are still feeding ???   Is this normal ?

Restarting the consumer, the exchange is "recreated"  but it seems that
some (or sometimes all) the bindings with the publishers are broken ???

This is how I am losing messages

Rabbitmq 3.1.5 


What do I do wrong ?


		Michel Grenier
		(514) 421-7204

From simon at rabbitmq.com  Thu Sep 12 15:09:56 2013
From: simon at rabbitmq.com (Simon MacMullen)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 15:09:56 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] when consumers goes away,
 how to delete their queues left behind
In-Reply-To: <7F414B031B795146A3697F7EF8C506675E3232@SQYL07EXMAIL7.quebec.int.ec.gc.ca>
References: <7F414B031B795146A3697F7EF8C506675E2EB2@SQYL07EXMAIL7.quebec.int.ec.gc.ca>
	<7F414B031B795146A3697F7EF8C5066756F0F8@SQYL07EXMAIL7.quebec.int.ec.gc.ca>
	<7F414B031B795146A3697F7EF8C506675E3232@SQYL07EXMAIL7.quebec.int.ec.gc.ca>
Message-ID: <5231CB34.1010900@rabbitmq.com>

You might find that queue expiry is what you want. See 
http://www.rabbitmq.com/ttl.html#queue-ttl

Cheers, Simon

From Andrew.Rendell at vocalink.com  Thu Sep 12 15:18:06 2013
From: Andrew.Rendell at vocalink.com (Andrew Rendell)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 15:18:06 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] RabbitMQ 'hang' when trying to access HA
 queues
In-Reply-To: <52319D7F.6090304@rabbitmq.com>
References: <8D76E9325134094DA4CFA89A132A4D640270D511BF@SPR3V9.office.local> 
	<523193E6.9020200@rabbitmq.com> 
	<8D76E9325134094DA4CFA89A132A4D640270D511EF@SPR3V9.office.local> 
	<52319D7F.6090304@rabbitmq.com>
Message-ID: <8D76E9325134094DA4CFA89A132A4D640270D51218@SPR3V9.office.local>

Hi Matthias,

Suchak and I got together and came up with a set of questions regarding our issue which if you were able to give feedback on, would be most useful.

We cannot be sure that during our 'hang' that publishers were blocked but from application behaviour, it seems likely, or at least they did not receive confirms. We do know that calls to queue declare (via the Java client) and rabbitmqctl list_queues both failed to return.

Our questions are:

- Are there any known conditions that you are aware of that would cause list_queues or declare queue to hang? If you are only able to indicate possible areas of the system that cause issue that would be helpful, e.g. if the MNESIA tables holding the queue metadata failed in some way (due to an infrastructure issue at the networking or disk level), could that explain one queue 'hanging'?
- The current documentation for RabbitMQ 3.x describes many situations where flow control kicks and publishers are blocked. We understand that flow control at 2.7.1 is rudimentary but it would simply involve publishers blocking (on basic publish) but could it in any way explain what we saw? (We are guessing not but wanted somebody who knows to confirm!).
- Some of our RabbitMQ clients are written in erlang and are embedded (with a significant amount of other application code) within the same cluster as RabbitMQ. Are there issues with this approach at 2.7.1?
- We are running the broker (and collocated application code) on Erlang R15B (erts-5.9) on Solaris SPARC. Again, are there any known issues with this configuration?

Thanks again for any support you can give us on this issue, I am aware you are going above and beyond the usual level of support especially given the version of RabbitMQ in use.

Regards, Andrew.

-----Original Message-----
From: Matthias Radestock [mailto:matthias at rabbitmq.com] 
Sent: 12 September 2013 11:55
To: Andrew Rendell
Cc: Discussions about RabbitMQ; Nick Gill (ngill at gopivotal.com); Suchak Jani
Subject: Re: [rabbitmq-discuss] RabbitMQ 'hang' when trying to access HA queues

Andrew,

On 12/09/13 11:41, Andrew Rendell wrote:
>> Was there anything unusual in the logs?
>
> No. This was what was most disconcerting about this issue.

Hmm. Quite.

> Would it be correct to say that since 2.7.1 there has been major 
> rewrites of the HA queue implementation

It's not been rewritten as such, but has undergone substantial change and improvement. There have been nearly 40 bug fixes to mirrored queues since 2.7.1.

> it is probable there were very few people using 2.7.1 in HA mode

...for a considerable length of time and/or with extensive testing...

> so a defect might have remain undiscovered?

Correct.

Matthias.

From matthias at rabbitmq.com  Thu Sep 12 16:08:30 2013
From: matthias at rabbitmq.com (Matthias Radestock)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 16:08:30 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] RabbitMQ 'hang' when trying to access HA
	queues
In-Reply-To: <8D76E9325134094DA4CFA89A132A4D640270D51218@SPR3V9.office.local>
References: <8D76E9325134094DA4CFA89A132A4D640270D511BF@SPR3V9.office.local>
	<523193E6.9020200@rabbitmq.com>
	<8D76E9325134094DA4CFA89A132A4D640270D511EF@SPR3V9.office.local>
	<52319D7F.6090304@rabbitmq.com>
	<8D76E9325134094DA4CFA89A132A4D640270D51218@SPR3V9.office.local>
Message-ID: <5231D8EE.5040602@rabbitmq.com>

Andrew,

On 12/09/13 15:18, Andrew Rendell wrote:
> - Are there any known conditions that you are aware of that would
> cause list_queues or declare queue to hang?

The fact that you don't see confirms, and declare and list_queue hangs 
all point to one thing: That the Erlang process for the queue (master, 
in case of mirrored queues) has gotten stuck.

Since you are not seeing any errors, the queue process is likely waiting
for some task to complete.

> We understand that flow control at 2.7.1 is rudimentary but it would
> simply involve publishers blocking (on basic publish) but could it in
> any way explain what we saw?

No, since that flow control - both old and new - wouldn't affect
list_queues. Besides, you'd know that flow control is happening
by the 'blocked' state of the connection in list_connections.

> Some of our RabbitMQ clients are written in erlang and are embedded
> (with a significant amount of other application code) within the same
> cluster as RabbitMQ. Are there issues with this approach at 2.7.1?

There shouldn't be any issue as long as these clients and associated
application code are "well behaved". Since you are sharing a VM with
rabbit, there is of course the potential for one to affect the other.
And the sort of embedding, at that scale, as you describe above is
somewhat off the well-trodden path. Still, I struggle to see how even a
mis-behaved embedded Erlang client / app could cause the symptoms you
describe.

> - We are running the broker (and collocated application code) on
> Erlang R15B (erts-5.9) on Solaris SPARC. Again, are there any known
> issues with this configuration?

R15B is quite ancient, so definitely recommend upgrading that. But, 
again, it's very unlikely that this is the source of your problem.


Regards,

Matthias.

Geoffrey,

> Internet Explorer 9 to work.  Are older browsers truly magically enabled
> to work with "websockets"?
>
>     SockJS is a WebSockets poly-fill that provides a WebSocket-like
>     JavaScript object in any browser. It will therefore work in older
>     browsers that don't have native WebSocket support, as well as in new
>     browsers that are behind WebSocket-unfriendly proxies.

says that IE9 works. It is possible that the sockjs version in rabbit is

developers.

From michael.s.klishin at gmail.com  Thu Sep 12 17:16:07 2013
From: michael.s.klishin at gmail.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 17:16:07 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] how to get the no of consumers for a
 publisher which is used type = fanout .
In-Reply-To: <557add72-0bf1-4ec0-98e9-5fdc51bf09af@googlegroups.com>
References: <557add72-0bf1-4ec0-98e9-5fdc51bf09af@googlegroups.com>
Message-ID: <CAE3HoVQA5pRWuV4q8jJECk1Mzg7McQ4F0apL4BiZ=W_T1Kh25Q@mail.gmail.com>

2013/9/12 Ramu M <mramu789 at gmail.com>

> how to get the no of consumers for a publisher which is used type = fanout
> .


You can get the # of consumers from queue.declare-ok (response to
queue.declare).

Exchanges don't have consumers, queues do. See
http://www.rabbitmq.com/tutorials/amqp-concepts.html
for more info.
-- 
MK

http://github.com/michaelklishin
http://twitter.com/michaelklishin

From Ron.Cordell at RelayHealth.com  Thu Sep 12 20:13:09 2013
From: Ron.Cordell at RelayHealth.com (Cordell, Ron)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 19:13:09 +0000
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Unable to list queues via rabbitmqctl or
	Management Plugin
Message-ID: <0B8CD6850421B745BE39BC5C7601923272010E25@DDCEP50016.na.corp.mckesson.com>

We are using the LDAP plugin to manage access to RabbitMQ. Here is the rabbit.config file:

[
  {rabbit, [{auth_backends, [rabbit_auth_backend_ldap]},
            {ssl_listeners, [5671]},
{frame_max, 0},
{cluster_partition_handling, pause_minority},
            {ssl_options, [{fail_if_no_peer_cert, false},
                          { verify, verify_none}]},
            {default_vhost, <<"/">>}]},
  {rabbitmq_auth_backend_ldap,
   [ {servers,               ["RHB.AD"]},
     {dn_lookup_attribute,   "userPrincipalName"},
     {dn_lookup_base,        "DC=RHB,DC=AD"},
     {user_dn_pattern,       "${username}@RHB.AD"},
     {use_ssl,               false},
     {port,                  389},
     {log,                   false},
     {vhost_access_query,    {in_group, "CN=INRMQ_DG - ${vhost} vHost Read Permissions,OU=INRMQ,OU=INTEGRATION,OU=Environments,OU=Servers,DC=RHB,DC=AD"}},
     {resource_access_query,
      {for, [{permission, configure, {in_group, "CN=INRMQ_DG - ${vhost} vHost Read Permissions,OU=INRMQ,OU=INTEGRATION,OU=Environments,OU=Servers,DC=RHB,DC=AD"}},
             {permission, write,
              {for, [{resource, queue,    {in_group, "CN=INRMQ_DG - ${vhost} vHost Write Permissions,OU=INRMQ,OU=INTEGRATION,OU=Environments,OU=Servers,DC=RHB,DC=AD"}},
                     {resource, exchange, {in_group, "CN=INRMQ_DG - ${vhost} vHost Write Permissions,OU=INRMQ,OU=INTEGRATION,OU=Environments,OU=Servers,DC=RHB,DC=AD"}}]}},
             {permission, read,
              {for, [{resource, exchange, {in_group, "CN=INRMQ_DG - ${vhost} vHost Read Permissions,OU=INRMQ,OU=INTEGRATION,OU=Environments,OU=Servers,DC=RHB,DC=AD"}},
                     {resource, queue,    {in_group, "CN=INRMQ_DG - ${vhost} vHost Read Permissions,OU=INRMQ,OU=INTEGRATION,OU=Environments,OU=Servers,DC=RHB,DC=AD"}}]}}
            ]
      }},

{tag_queries,    [{management,  {in_group, "CN=INRMQ_DG - RabbitMQ User Access Management,OU=INRMQ,OU=INTEGRATION,OU=Environments,OU=Servers,DC=RHB,DC=AD"}},
 {monitoring,        {in_group, "CN=INRMQ_DG - RabbitMQ User Access Monitoring,OU=INRMQ,OU=INTEGRATION,OU=Environments,OU=Servers,DC=RHB,DC=AD"}},
 {administrator,     {in_group, "CN=Access Profile - SCM,OU=Access Profiles,OU=Servers,DC=RHB,DC=AD"}},
                      {administrator,     {in_group, "CN=INRMQ_DG - RabbitMQ User Access Administrator,OU=INRMQ,OU=INTEGRATION,OU=Environments,OU=Servers,DC=RHB,DC=AD"}}]}
   ]
  }
].
My user is in all groups.

I am able to see all the queues from the Management Plugin.
However, I am not able to list queues from the rabbitmqctl command:


Microsoft Windows [Version 6.1.7601]
Copyright (c) 2009 Microsoft Corporation.  All rights reserved.

From randeep at pubnub.com  Thu Sep 12 21:54:08 2013
From: randeep at pubnub.com (Randy Kang)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 13:54:08 -0700
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Web-Stomp Plugin browser support
In-Reply-To: <5231E2FC.8020309@rabbitmq.com>
References: <CAJc-UNufcwxUbF=ZMkHpzYo_rXL6BcFQX0bF+UsQAXVw3zj-hA@mail.gmail.com>
	<5231E2FC.8020309@rabbitmq.com>
Message-ID: <839E500C-46D7-4749-AEEF-114B444B7604@pubnub.com>

if you can't get SockJS to work on IE9, you can try my adapter instead.  i just published it on github and it connects RabbitMQ to web and mobile clients.  there's a tutorial and code samples on this blog post:
http://www.pubnub.com/blog/extend-rabbitmq-into-mobile-and-web-using-pubnub/

the adapter works as an AMQP client to consume/produce with RabbitMQ and it works as a web client to publish/subscribe to the PubNub network.  then the PubNub network connects to any mobile/web clients on the appropriate channel.

On the browser side, you can just use PubNub's simple api to publish/subscribe.

-- 
thanks,
randy kang
developer/evangelist
PubNub
650-260-5264

From michael at rabbitmq.com  Thu Sep 12 22:04:34 2013
From: michael at rabbitmq.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2013 22:04:34 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] reusing auto-generated queue name
In-Reply-To: <7F414B031B795146A3697F7EF8C506675E32D8@SQYL07EXMAIL7.quebec.int.ec.gc.ca>
References: <0B8CD6850421B745BE39BC5C7601923272010E25@DDCEP50016.na.corp.mckesson.com>
	<7F414B031B795146A3697F7EF8C506675E32D8@SQYL07EXMAIL7.quebec.int.ec.gc.ca>
Message-ID: <D5C3689E-F592-4182-A462-BA03DD106D55@rabbitmq.com>

Grenier,Michel [CMC]:

> Can?t it  redeclare/bind with that name  to resume my message delivery ?

Applications cannot declare entities that start with amq.

Server-named queues are supposed to be used (and declared) only by consumers. It makes
no sense to use them if you share the name between multiple services. In that case, use
well known names that do not start with amq.

If you really need to share a server-named queue name, you can declare them with passive = true
which will simply do nothing if the queue exists and raise a channel exception if the queue
does not exist.

MK

RabbitMQ paste unack message to the end of a queue?

From matthias at rabbitmq.com  Fri Sep 13 07:28:26 2013

On 13/09/13 07:03, Haster wrote:
> why after such problems order of messages changes?
> For example I send 1,2,3,4,5 messages (prefetch count is 20) and on 6
> message I have problem...

By "problem" do you mean the client disconnects and reconnects?

And when you reconnect, has rabbitmq definitely seen the old connection 
disappear? Check the server logs for the sequencing of the 
connect/disconnect events.

> After network problem the next processed message is 25, but not 6.
> RabbitMQ paste unack message to the end of a queue?

Not in recent versions. though there are some caveats. See 
http://www.rabbitmq.com/semantics.html#ordering

If you have a scenario where you think the ordering semantics defined on 
that page is violated, then capture a trace with the RabbitMQ protocol 
tracer (http://www.rabbitmq.com/api-guide.html#tracer), inspect the 
output, and if after that you still think there is a problem then post 
the trace here.

Matthias.

From michael at rabbitmq.com  Fri Sep 13 09:26:38 2013
From: michael at rabbitmq.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2013 09:26:38 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] is there any Pollar concept in the rabbit mq
	, just like zmq.Poller() which is present in the  zero mq
In-Reply-To: <2adf544b-be81-4893-93ac-3954779c8fe5@googlegroups.com>
References: <2adf544b-be81-4893-93ac-3954779c8fe5@googlegroups.com>
Message-ID: <366F3B2E-BCC5-4E1F-A77F-F898FCF3FFBE@rabbitmq.com>

rajjs:

> is there any Pollar concept in the rabbit mq ,  just like zmq.Poller() which is present in the  zero mq 

There are two ways to consume messages from RabbitMQ:

 * "Push API" (basic.consume, creating a long-running subscription)
 * "Pull API" (basic.get, very similar to HTTP GET)

MK

Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Strange behaviour of RabbitMQ or client when

	<5232B08A.1010204@rabbitmq.com>
	<1379061863984-29597.post@n5.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <F07EDA43-FB30-45CB-89F8-1E7D146B343D@rabbitmq.com>

Haster:

> I don't have a possibility to get trace, but I think that new connection is
> started before the server
> delete old connection. 

It takes time to detect dead connections and TCP will try redelivery first. This is why
RabbitMQ has heartbeats, to detect that the peer has disconnect earlier.

> And how I can avoid this situation? I don't know when server find connection
> error and close old connection. 

If you use REJECT for TCP traffic on a firewall, it does not immediately indicate that the connection
is closed to RabbitMQ. Either find a different way of testing what you are trying to test,
or set heartbeat interval to a low value (e.g. a few seconds).

MK

Message-ID: <ED1B3DA7-B727-4820-B43A-2021FAD9B7AE@rabbitmq.com>

ramkkk:

> is there any way send the response message from the each subscriber to the
> publisher in rabbit mq, when exhange_type="fanout".

Consumers know nothing about publishers unless publishers include some information
into message metadata. See https://www.rabbitmq.com/tutorials/tutorial-six-python.html
for a common request/reply implementation.

MK

From simon at rabbitmq.com  Fri Sep 13 10:03:00 2013
From: simon at rabbitmq.com (Simon MacMullen)
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2013 10:03:00 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Using RabbitMQ 3.1.5 on windows plugins keep
 disappearing
In-Reply-To: <2b83006a-bbe6-4cbc-9fc1-112efe48be09@googlegroups.com>
References: <2b83006a-bbe6-4cbc-9fc1-112efe48be09@googlegroups.com>
Message-ID: <5232D4C4.6090800@rabbitmq.com>

On 13/09/13 05:10, Robert Gilland wrote:
> Every time the system restarts I lose all my enabled plugins what could
> possibly be happening?

The enabled plugins file is stored in %RABBITMQ_BASE% - by default, 
%APPDATA%\RabbitMQ\enabled_plugins.

So is %APPDATA% somehow non-persistent across reboots on your machine? 
If so you probably want to point %RABBITMQ_BASE% elsewhere since that 
contains the message store too!

See http://www.rabbitmq.com/relocate.html for more information.

Cheers, Simon

-- 
Simon MacMullen
RabbitMQ, Pivotal

Message-ID: <98CCC16D-FAA1-4979-BC4C-975546690188@rabbitmq.com>

Haster:

> And how can I set heartbeat value using rabbitmq-c?

It has to be specified during connection negotiation, so look at
various connection options. I'm not sure if librabbitmq-c actually
supports heartbeats.

> Is it enough to past such value to amqp_basic_qos method?

basic.qos controls prefetch value for a channel, not heartbeats

MK

From Michel.Grenier at ssc-spc.gc.ca  Fri Sep 13 13:28:02 2013
From: Michel.Grenier at ssc-spc.gc.ca (Grenier,Michel [CMC])
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2013 08:28:02 -0400
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] reusing auto-generated queue name
In-Reply-To: <D5C3689E-F592-4182-A462-BA03DD106D55@rabbitmq.com>
References: <0B8CD6850421B745BE39BC5C7601923272010E25@DDCEP50016.na.corp.mckesson.com><7F414B031B795146A3697F7EF8C506675E32D8@SQYL07EXMAIL7.quebec.int.ec.gc.ca>
	<D5C3689E-F592-4182-A462-BA03DD106D55@rabbitmq.com>
Message-ID: <7F414B031B795146A3697F7EF8C506675E3302@SQYL07EXMAIL7.quebec.int.ec.gc.ca>

I did not want to share.
My consumer was stopped.  At that time the queue was piling up messages
for my consumer.
When restarting my consumer, I simply wanted to declare it and rebind
that auto-generated named queue.
I understand that it is not possible.

		Michel Grenier
		(514) 421-7204



-----Original Message-----
From: rabbitmq-discuss-bounces at lists.rabbitmq.com
[mailto:rabbitmq-discuss-bounces at lists.rabbitmq.com] On Behalf Of
Michael Klishin
Sent: 12 September, 2013 17:05
To: Discussions about RabbitMQ
Subject: Re: [rabbitmq-discuss] reusing auto-generated queue name

Grenier,Michel [CMC]:

> Can't it  redeclare/bind with that name  to resume my message delivery
?

Applications cannot declare entities that start with amq.

Server-named queues are supposed to be used (and declared) only by
consumers. It makes no sense to use them if you share the name between
multiple services. In that case, use well known names that do not start
with amq.

If you really need to share a server-named queue name, you can declare
them with passive = true which will simply do nothing if the queue
exists and raise a channel exception if the queue does not exist.

MK

From mklishin at gopivotal.com  Fri Sep 13 16:35:30 2013
From: mklishin at gopivotal.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2013 16:35:30 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Rabbit issues
In-Reply-To: <CALC7yyASb8T4=5xRG0EWhLvqO1Xon7zvFEPMPepB_Dgr2z6e7w@mail.gmail.com>
References: <CALC7yyASBtgZnZRdhD=PL_h-mZYRoXuN_UsEN=oaabtQYSi8tw@mail.gmail.com>
	<7BE4093E-8767-4A57-9A6E-C75744C44A8A@rabbitmq.com>
	<CALC7yyASb8T4=5xRG0EWhLvqO1Xon7zvFEPMPepB_Dgr2z6e7w@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <A1920EB3-1429-4E1F-8119-42A809A20048@gopivotal.com>

Seenivasan Gopalsamy:

> 3 node cluster  and one of the cluster node is Shovel . i can able to
> see the above mentioned  messages in rabbit log .
> Error : HTTP Channel started timeout 300/900/2000
> and  Timeout
> 
> these node are sending messages and receiving messages.
> 
> 
> usually i will get the following messages.
> 
> =INFO REPORT==== 13-Sep-2013::06:18:33 ===
> accepting AMQP connection
> 
> =WARNING REPORT==== 13-Sep-2013::06:18:33 ===
> closing AMQP connection
> connection_closed_abruptly

This particular warnings means that an AMQP 0-9-1 connection wasn't closed
properly by a client (it just terminated TCP connection instead). This is harmless.

JSON-RPC uses long polling so if a browser client goes away without properly
disconnecting, you will see the HTTP Channel timeout (it should be a warning, too).
Again, this is harmless and indicates clients not disconnecting properly.

Also, have you considered using SockJS or WebSTOMP with the STOMP plugin?
JSON-RPC is a pretty old plugin that is not being actively worked on.
--
MK

Software Engineer, Pivotal/RabbitMQ

From michael.oullion at norbert-dentressangle.com  Fri Sep 13 16:00:10 2013
From: michael.oullion at norbert-dentressangle.com (Michael Oullion)
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2013 08:00:10 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Java Client and Admin
Message-ID: <c1bb987e-8e5b-4bda-a489-4e7da057ff3b@googlegroups.com>

Hello, 
We have two questions about the Java API :

   1. We want to check if a specific policy exist and, if necessary create 
   it, and assign it to the right queue.
   Is there a way to do this with the Java client ?
   
   2. We observe , with a mirrored queue, that if we are not connected to 
   the Master Node ( aka the node which hosted the queue), We have less 
   performance on consuming messages.
   Is it normal? (queue mirrored on 2 node, queue persistent and messages 
   persistent)
   If yes, we want to get the master node of the queue to connect on it.
   Is there a way to get this information with the java client api?

We know that we can realize this 2 "actions" with the REST API but, if it's 
possible I don't want to mix administration of my rabbitmq between java api 
and rest api.

Regards, 
Mike
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.rabbitmq.com/pipermail/rabbitmq-discuss/attachments/20130913/ac75bbe0/attachment.htm>

From mklishin at gopivotal.com  Fri Sep 13 16:43:07 2013
From: mklishin at gopivotal.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2013 16:43:07 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Java Client and Admin
In-Reply-To: <c1bb987e-8e5b-4bda-a489-4e7da057ff3b@googlegroups.com>
References: <c1bb987e-8e5b-4bda-a489-4e7da057ff3b@googlegroups.com>
Message-ID: <31038DC7-293C-4BF9-A83C-5F6AA3A222B5@rabbitmq.com>

Michael Oullion:

> We have two questions about the Java API :
> 	? We want to check if a specific policy exist and, if necessary create it, and assign it to the right queue.
> Is there a way to do this with the Java client ?

RabbitMQ Java client is AMQP 0-9-1, HTTP API currently does not have a Java client
(at least the official one).

> 
> 	? We observe , with a mirrored queue, that if we are not connected to the Master Node ( aka the node which hosted the queue), We have less performance on consuming messages.
> Is it normal? (queue mirrored on 2 node, queue persistent and messages persistent)

Yes, because then the node that your consumer is connected to has to request messages
from the master. Intra-cluster communication takes some time.

> If yes, we want to get the master node of the queue to connect on it.
> Is there a way to get this information with the java client api?

HTTP API provides the information you are looking for.

/api/queues/{vhost}/{queue} should contain "node" key that indicates
which node is master.

MK

> if I can do this with the RabbitMQ Java Client (http://www.rabbitmq.com/java-client.html)

There is no way to do this in AMQP 0-9-1 and thus the Java client. Using HTTP API
is the only way.

From ben.hsu at criticalmedia.com  Fri Sep 13 23:07:14 2013
From: ben.hsu at criticalmedia.com (Ben Hsu)
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2013 18:07:14 -0400
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] =?utf-8?q?Proper_process_to_change_erlang_cook?=
	=?utf-8?b?aWU/?=
Message-ID: <etPan.52338c92.22cc3dbb.22ad@heartoftheneutronstar.local>

Hello all

I need to change the erlang cookie on my RabbitMQ server to get clustering working, and wish to know the correct procedure.

I tried doing this:

rabbitmqctl stop_app
vi /var/lib/rabbitmq/.erlang.cookie
rabbitmqctl start_app # this gave me an error message:?Error: unable to connect to node 'rabbit at ben-amqp-test4': nodedown

By trial and error, I found this worked:
pkill beam
pkill epmd
vi /var/lib/rabbitmq/.erlang.cookie
rabbitmq-server?
# now in a separate window, for some reason it didn't work with rabbitmq-server -detached
rabbitmqctl start_app

That seemed to work, but is ugly, and doesn't feel like the right way of doing it.

Also, what is the difference between "rabbitmqctl start_app" and "rabbitmq-server"?

Thanks in advance

--?
Ben Hsu
Sent with Airmail
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.rabbitmq.com/pipermail/rabbitmq-discuss/attachments/20130913/3b0ab9c9/attachment.htm>

From videlalvaro at gmail.com  Fri Sep 13 23:16:29 2013
From: videlalvaro at gmail.com (Alvaro Videla)
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2013 15:16:29 -0700
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Proper process to change erlang cookie?
In-Reply-To: <etPan.52338c92.22cc3dbb.22ad@heartoftheneutronstar.local>
References: <etPan.52338c92.22cc3dbb.22ad@heartoftheneutronstar.local>
Message-ID: <CAMcAHLVY2B-RFTnCLh12Fh28T=LRjheiSE5uQ3ELrQmeKCancg@mail.gmail.com>

The Erlang cookie belongs to each particular user on your machines.
The cookie can be found on ~/.erlang.cookie and you need to have the same
value there for every node in the cluster.

start_app stops the Rabbit application inside the Erlang VM but the VM has
to be running for that to work.

stop_app will stop the rabbit app, but not the Erlang VM

rabbitmq-server takes care of preparing the env parameters and starting the
Erlang VM to then run RabbitMQ on it.

Regards,

Alvaro

On Friday, September 13, 2013, Ben Hsu wrote:

> Hello all
>
> I need to change the erlang cookie on my RabbitMQ server to get clustering
> working, and wish to know the correct procedure.
>

> rabbitmqctl stop_app
> vi /var/lib/rabbitmq/.erlang.cookie
> rabbitmqctl start_app # this gave me an error message: *Error: unable to
> connect to node 'rabbit at ben-amqp-test4': nodedown*
>
> By trial and error, I found this worked:
> pkill beam
> pkill epmd
> vi /var/lib/rabbitmq/.erlang.cookie
> rabbitmq-server
> # now in a separate window, for some reason it didn't work with
> rabbitmq-server -detached
> rabbitmqctl start_app
>
> That seemed to work, but is ugly, and doesn't feel like the right way of
> doing it.
>

> "rabbitmq-server"?

From tilak.chauhan at ymail.com  Sat Sep 14 07:17:01 2013
From: tilak.chauhan at ymail.com (tluck)
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2013 23:17:01 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Mnesia crashes on rmq clustering !
Message-ID: <1379139421110-29634.post@n5.nabble.com>

Hi,

I've setup rmq clustering on multiple severs with HA queues. But recently
I've noticed one issue with clustering and that is it fails after every
couple of days. When I did some investigation with rmq log files then I saw
following issues logged there :

=ERROR REPORT==== 10-Sep-2013::16:02:30 ===
Mnesia(rabbit at producer): ** ERROR ** mnesia_event got
    {inconsistent_database, running_partitioned_network, rabbit at consumer01}


After reading couple of posts by other people on this issue I get to know
this problem is because inter-network communication failure / network
partition. Though it sounds very difficult for me to move all servers into
same network to get rid of this problem.

Are shovel and federation are good use here over clustering ? If yes ? then
which one is faster and issue free.

Thanks in advance.
Tluck



--
View this message in context: http://rabbitmq.1065348.n5.nabble.com/Mnesia-crashes-on-rmq-clustering-tp29634.html
Sent from the RabbitMQ mailing list archive at Nabble.com.

From michael at rabbitmq.com  Sat Sep 14 10:19:29 2013
From: michael at rabbitmq.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Sat, 14 Sep 2013 10:19:29 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Mnesia crashes on rmq clustering !
In-Reply-To: <1379139421110-29634.post@n5.nabble.com>
References: <1379139421110-29634.post@n5.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <0329718D-B6A1-4ADD-AE05-0FB4C200338C@rabbitmq.com>

tluck:

> Are shovel and federation are good use here over clustering ? If yes ? then
> which one is faster and issue free.

Shovel and federation both use AMQP 0-9-1 connections which will be recovered.
Note that both are asynchronous replication tools (AP in CAP), while clustering
is CP.

See http://www.rabbitmq.com/clustering.html
and http://www.rabbitmq.com/ha.html.

MK



-------------- next part --------------

Name: signature.asc
Type: application/pgp-signature
Size: 495 bytes
Desc: Message signed with OpenPGP using GPGMail
URL: <http://lists.rabbitmq.com/pipermail/rabbitmq-discuss/attachments/20130914/4d0501fb/attachment.pgp>

From watson.timothy at gmail.com  Sat Sep 14 18:23:03 2013
From: watson.timothy at gmail.com (Tim Watson)
Date: Sat, 14 Sep 2013 18:23:03 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Mnesia crashes on rmq clustering !
In-Reply-To: <0329718D-B6A1-4ADD-AE05-0FB4C200338C@rabbitmq.com>
References: <1379139421110-29634.post@n5.nabble.com>
	<0329718D-B6A1-4ADD-AE05-0FB4C200338C@rabbitmq.com>
Message-ID: <FF2C1876-EB23-4AD9-A73F-06C873F30CEB@rabbitmq.com>

Just to add to what Michael said: no replication scheme in a distributed system will be "issue free", but the right tool(s) will enable you to manage the challenges that distribution entails.

Shovel and Federation both provide a means for replicating state across a wide area (or other) network, but require that you write your client in such a way that it can handle duplication (which is good practise anyway). Clustering/HA provides transparent replication without message loss, but doesn't handle network partitions well.

You can, therefore, decide where to invest effort in building your system - either in preventing or handling (through infrastructure management) partitions, or in handling replication yourself. It's advisable to focus your efforts on (a) the scenario you're most likely to encounter vs the risks involved,  and/or (b) the solution and technology with which you're more comfortable (e.g., managing replication over AMQP or handling network design, dealing with partitions using various sysops tools).

Cheers,
Tim

From videlalvaro at gmail.com  Sat Sep 14 18:51:56 2013
From: videlalvaro at gmail.com (Alvaro Videla)
Date: Sat, 14 Sep 2013 10:51:56 -0700
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Proper process to change erlang cookie?
In-Reply-To: <etPan.52339570.3c387f34.22ad@heartoftheneutronstar.local>
References: <etPan.52338c92.22cc3dbb.22ad@heartoftheneutronstar.local>
	<CAMcAHLVY2B-RFTnCLh12Fh28T=LRjheiSE5uQ3ELrQmeKCancg@mail.gmail.com>
	<etPan.52339570.3c387f34.22ad@heartoftheneutronstar.local>
Message-ID: <CAMcAHLX4Q3V_dT74kCDdMm=Ms1Kh8nU1G5XcRtB__gkObGc_vw@mail.gmail.com>

You will have one Erlang cookie per user that started a distributed Erlang
VM. Say you run RrabbitMQ as the user "rabbit". Erlang will create a cookie
for that user.

Then with your own user you try to run rabbitmqctl. That will create an
Erlang cookie in your home folder, and that cookie _won't_ match the one
created for RabbitMQ. What you have to do is either make sure both files
have the same content, or set the cookie during startup, or update it
afterwards to match the one of the other node you are trying to connect to.

See: http://www.erlang.org/doc/reference_manual/distributed.html#id83622


On Fri, Sep 13, 2013 at 3:45 PM, Ben Hsu <ben.hsu at criticalmedia.com> wrote:

> Thank you Alvaro,
>
>
> I understand  the difference between rabbitmq-server and rabbitmqctl now.
>
>
> I'm still not able to copy or edit the Erlang cookie without killing the
> process. I see two different .erlang.cookie files: one in /var/lib/rabbitmq
> and one in the users home directory. I copied the first to the second and
> still got the "unable to connect" problem
>
>
> I am running version 3.1.3.1 on CentOS
> -- Ben HsuSent with Airmail <http://airmailapp.com/tracking>
>
> On September 13, 2013 at 7:39:41 PM, Ben Hsu (ben.hsu at criticalmedia.com)
> wrote:
>
> The Erlang cookie belongs to each particular user on your machines.
> The cookie can be found on ~/.erlang.cookie and you need to have the same
> value there for every node in the cluster.
>
> start_app stops the Rabbit application inside the Erlang VM but the VM has
> to be running for that to work.
>
> stop_app will stop the rabbit app, but not the Erlang VM
>
> rabbitmq-server takes care of preparing the env parameters and starting
> the Erlang VM to then run RabbitMQ on it.
>
> Regards,
>
> Alvaro
>
> On Friday, September 13, 2013, Ben Hsu wrote:
>

>> connect to node 'rabbit at ben-amqp-test4': nodedown*
>>
>> By trial and error, I found this worked:
>> pkill beam
>> pkill epmd
>> vi /var/lib/rabbitmq/.erlang.cookie
>> rabbitmq-server
>> # now in a separate window, for some reason it didn't work with
>> rabbitmq-server -detached
>> rabbitmqctl start_app
>>
>> That seemed to work, but is ugly, and doesn't feel like the right way of

skavans:

> By default when I send a message with absent routing_key, the broker rejects
> it. How can I force RabitMQ to send one to the some 'default' queue?

Publish with mandatory = true and it will be returned to the client. Or try AE [1].

1. http://www.rabbitmq.com/ae.html

From videlalvaro at gmail.com  Sun Sep 15 08:33:06 2013
From: videlalvaro at gmail.com (Alvaro Videla)
Date: Sun, 15 Sep 2013 00:33:06 -0700
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] RabbitMQ custom exchange (script-exchange
 installation trouble)
In-Reply-To: <1379227656209-29642.post@n5.nabble.com>
References: <1379204450858-29639.post@n5.nabble.com>
	<1379227656209-29642.post@n5.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <CAMcAHLVAK88AsnuWVxkpsWFoJn2BRF70BYNY1_HskRS5vi+DhA@mail.gmail.com>

You need to have a queue bound to the Alternate Exchange. Then later you
can add a consumer and process the messages from that queue. Keep in mind
that you don't need consumers for the messages to be queued, you need
queues for that.

The example on that page show's how to set all up.

From michael.s.klishin at gmail.com  Sun Sep 15 11:07:42 2013
From: michael.s.klishin at gmail.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Sun, 15 Sep 2013 11:07:42 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] RabbitMQ custom exchange (script-exchange
 installation trouble)
In-Reply-To: <1379239389873-29644.post@n5.nabble.com>
References: <1379204450858-29639.post@n5.nabble.com>
	<1379239389873-29644.post@n5.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <CAE3HoVQUkTz=JGBL6M86gBZrY4mWMCBC1oXCp68JmvsjUecV3A@mail.gmail.com>

2013/9/15 skavans <vans.zarya at gmail.com>

> I want
> the 'default' consumers process messages having an absent routing key ('q3'
> for example). However, when I send the message with key 'q3' it will resend
> to alternate exchange and reject there because AE does not know what to do
> with messages with 'q3' key
>

Make your AE a fanout so that it routes everything to the queue named
'default'.

You keep saying "rejected", unroutable messages are not rejected, they are
either

1. Returned to the client
2. Re-published to AE
3. Dropped

In case of 2, you need to make sure that AE can route them somewhere, like
with
any other exchange.
-- 
MK

http://github.com/michaelklishin
http://twitter.com/michaelklishin

From michael.s.klishin at gmail.com  Sun Sep 15 12:02:56 2013
From: michael.s.klishin at gmail.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Sun, 15 Sep 2013 12:02:56 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] RabbitMQ custom exchange (script-exchange
 installation trouble)
In-Reply-To: <1379242089614-29647.post@n5.nabble.com>
References: <1379204450858-29639.post@n5.nabble.com>
	<1379242089614-29647.post@n5.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <CAE3HoVTFpXvoG+b6TW6O3ve8YsNLJ91=8PHga+-jLCyMGDXKSQ@mail.gmail.com>

2013/9/15 skavans <vans.zarya at gmail.com>

> it will be excellent if my AE can
> send messages in round-robin-like way. Is it possible to do that?
>

1. consistent-hash-exchange (bundled with rabbitmq, needs to be enabled via
rabbitmq-plugin)
2. round-robin distribution happens between consumers on a shared queue

From Rohit.Patel2 at techmahindra.com  Sun Sep 15 12:45:26 2013
From: Rohit.Patel2 at techmahindra.com (Rohit Patle)
Date: Sun, 15 Sep 2013 11:45:26 +0000
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Message stuck at listener queue (Some times)!!
Message-ID: <27E054594442884E9A46DBCF9AE7408160F6C9@BSDMSATMBX001.mahindrasatyam.ad>

Hi,

I am working client-server based design using rabbitmq 3.1.5, In my design I am publishing message from client with specific routing key and listening at server by creating queues(Durable and giving explicit ack) with Exactly same name. But I am facing issue that some times at  my listener the message stuck into the listener queue(which is durable) at server end. And if I try again and again to publish on same queue the messages just get queued into queue and my listener unable to get the request from publisher.

My question is How I can make sure that any message should not stuck into the queue and deliver without fail to the listener??

Please Help.

Thanks you,
Rohit

From videlalvaro at gmail.com  Sun Sep 15 20:09:44 2013
From: videlalvaro at gmail.com (Alvaro Videla)
Date: Sun, 15 Sep 2013 12:09:44 -0700
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Message stuck at listener queue (Some
	times)!!
In-Reply-To: <27E054594442884E9A46DBCF9AE7408160F6C9@BSDMSATMBX001.mahindrasatyam.ad>
References: <27E054594442884E9A46DBCF9AE7408160F6C9@BSDMSATMBX001.mahindrasatyam.ad>
Message-ID: <CAMcAHLU6GzcX__NanMC6Uzov0zzVV0mfi5PCxEJx6-c6_QxQQA@mail.gmail.com>

Hi Rohit,

On Sun, Sep 15, 2013 at 4:45 AM, Rohit Patle
<Rohit.Patel2 at techmahindra.com>wrote:
>
>
> My question is How I can make sure that any message should not stuck into
> the queue and deliver without fail to the listener??
>

What do you mean by this? If a queue has consumers, then it will deliver
the messages to them. If the consumer then ack's the message, it will be
deleted from the queue.
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.rabbitmq.com/pipermail/rabbitmq-discuss/attachments/20130915/34bb4faf/attachment.htm>

From michael at rabbitmq.com  Sun Sep 15 20:13:03 2013
From: michael at rabbitmq.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Sun, 15 Sep 2013 20:13:03 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Message stuck at listener queue (Some
	times)!!
In-Reply-To: <27E054594442884E9A46DBCF9AE7408160F6C9@BSDMSATMBX001.mahindrasatyam.ad>
References: <27E054594442884E9A46DBCF9AE7408160F6C9@BSDMSATMBX001.mahindrasatyam.ad>
Message-ID: <19B915CA-F449-4A56-A8E1-71F57227FF3B@rabbitmq.com>

Rohit Patle:

> But I am facing issue that some times at  my listener the message stuck into the listener queue(which is durable) at server end. And if I try again and again to publish on same queue the messages just get queued into queue and my listener unable to get the request from publisher.

It's not very clear what you mean by "stuck into the listener queue at server end". If you shut down your
consumer without acknowledging messages, RabbitMQ will notice and re-queue them. Either
use automatic acknowledgements or always ack or reject messages before consumer apps
shut down.

> My question is How I can make sure that any message should not stuck into the queue and deliver without fail to the listener??

Again, not sure what you are doing.

Messages should be delivered to consumers with respect to channel's prefetch (delivery limit) value.
By default it is "no limit".

See Tutorial 2:
https://www.rabbitmq.com/getstarted.html

for more information and please post relevant snippets of your code and maybe a RabbitMQ
management UI screenshot(s).

MK

From matthias at rabbitmq.com  Mon Sep 16 07:46:07 2013
From: matthias at rabbitmq.com (Matthias Radestock)
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 2013 07:46:07 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Mnesia crashes on rmq clustering !
In-Reply-To: <1379311599319-29657.post@n5.nabble.com>
References: <1379139421110-29634.post@n5.nabble.com>
	<0329718D-B6A1-4ADD-AE05-0FB4C200338C@rabbitmq.com>
	<FF2C1876-EB23-4AD9-A73F-06C873F30CEB@rabbitmq.com>
	<1379249668910-29649.post@n5.nabble.com>
	<5235DB5B.9010303@rabbitmq.com>
	<1379311599319-29657.post@n5.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <5236A92F.1030609@rabbitmq.com>

On 16/09/13 07:06, ding wrote:
>>> Why do you have 20 servers ? Why not just one? Or perhaps two (for fault
> tolerance)?
>
> We do some site scrapping and for that we need different IPs to save
> yourself from being blocked by the site. This is why we have 20 servers for
> handling all this.

AMQP is a client-server protocol. Producers and consumers can run on 
different machines from the server. So I don't understand why you need a 
cluster of 20 *rabbit* servers. A single server, with 1 producer and ~20 
consumer machines connecting to it should suffice.

Matthias.

From mklishin at gopivotal.com  Mon Sep 16 12:15:02 2013
From: mklishin at gopivotal.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 2013 12:15:02 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] how i can found the performance is slow in
	the rabbit mq
In-Reply-To: <1379329878059-29667.post@n5.nabble.com>
References: <1379329878059-29667.post@n5.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <5E469883-6448-4F7C-8621-4867ADD362C9@rabbitmq.com>

ramkkk:

> how i can found the performance is slow in the rabbit mq, is it based on the
> message_rates ??

Are you trying to monitor a Rabbit node/cluster and want to alert on
message rates being lower than some expected value?

HTTP API can help with that:
http://hg.rabbitmq.com/rabbitmq-management/raw-file/3646dee55e02/priv/www-api/help.html

Note that those rates indicate throughput, which is only one metric.
Some systems care much more about latency.

MK

Bernhard Mogens Ege:

> Suggestions to the cause of the crash?

Running

C:\\Windows\\system32\\cmd.exe /cdir /-C /W \"c:/Users/bme/AppData/Roaming/RabbitMQ/db/rabbit at APPS-mnesia\"

fails due to "eacces" (likely insufficient permissions).

Check if anything has changed around RabbitMQ user and/or
the directory permissions.

MK

On sep 16, 2013, at 12:37 p.m., ramkkk <mramu789 at gmail.com> wrote:

> let me explain my requirement , suppose  in the particular node. the
> performance is slow means so automatically i have to increase the no workers
> . so that to improve the performance ..
> so for that reason , how want know , how i can  find the performance is slow

RabbitMQ HTTP API should provide you pretty detailed information about
message rates for individual queues. Use those metrics to implement the
scaling logic you need.

MK

UPDATE:

just wanted to share what I was missing for the intent and the app to fire ok:
I completely missed the <uses-permission android:name="android.permission.INTERNET"></uses-permission>

without this line the intent was not firing the right way..
I am targeting a min sdk of 7

Now the app builds and runs , I am facing another issue: the fact that I cannot perform a networking operation on a main thread (pic shows logs)..
I have read that the Best way is to do an Async Task..
trying to figure out the code for it...

From phillpafford at gmail.com  Mon Sep 16 15:41:56 2013
From: phillpafford at gmail.com (Phill Pafford)
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 2013 07:41:56 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Mobile Client Request [ iOS/Android/HTML5/etc...]
Message-ID: <56f0a17c-2c4f-4bda-badc-4c5d577ca114@googlegroups.com>

Would like to start the discussion on what ( if any ) the Mobile Client for 
RabbitMQ should look like in terms of functionality / features.

For me I would like to see the following:

- Overview ( Something like the management plugin overview tab )
  * minus the import / export functionality

- Connections

- Queues
  * With get and submit message functionality

- Admin
  * User creation/permissions

Would also like to see some sort of alert functionality ( Push 
Notifications ) for:

- Node Down
- Server Restart
- Disc Space
- RAM usage

if anyone else has some ideas as to what should be in the mobile 
app/client, feel free to voice them here

From Chris.Nicel at 15below.com  Mon Sep 16 15:48:45 2013
From: Chris.Nicel at 15below.com (Chris Nicel)

Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Performance and load testing of RMQ
In-Reply-To: <1379341875107-29675.post@n5.nabble.com>
References: <1379341875107-29675.post@n5.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <A57B6B00637AF741A9FA2D006B40C3C883C86B2D4C@AUSP01VMBX29.collaborationhost.net>

I wrote an application based on EasyNetQ which is available for use by anyone.

https://github.com/chrisedebo/RabbitMQ.LoadTest

It will require a set of text files which are randomly passed across the message bus by the publishers. The subscriber will retrieve these messages and output a count to the console.

Have a look and let me know if you need any assistance with it.

From sagu.prf1 at gmail.com  Mon Sep 16 16:40:25 2013
From: sagu.prf1 at gmail.com (sagu prf)
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 2013 08:40:25 -0700
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] regarding HTTP Channel started Time out , closing
Message-ID: <CAMK+tBipj2g+r=z3g3zJ46V+vg1CZAd9t4_iub=Y7_760mnJXQ@mail.gmail.com>

Hello Team ,

             I am getting following errors frequently , could you
please advise me ?

/var/log/rabbitmq$ tail -10o rabbit at linuxserv1 |grep time
HTTP Channel timed out, closing.
HTTP Channel timed out, closing.
HTTP Channel timed out, closing.
HTTP Channel started, timeout 2000
HTTP Channel started, timeout 300
HTTP Channel started, timeout 900

RabbitMQ version 2.8.7 with Erlang R15B02

Regards
sagu

From simon at rabbitmq.com  Mon Sep 16 16:51:35 2013
From: simon at rabbitmq.com (Simon MacMullen)
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 2013 16:51:35 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] regarding HTTP Channel started Time out ,
 closing
In-Reply-To: <CAMK+tBipj2g+r=z3g3zJ46V+vg1CZAd9t4_iub=Y7_760mnJXQ@mail.gmail.com>
References: <CAMK+tBipj2g+r=z3g3zJ46V+vg1CZAd9t4_iub=Y7_760mnJXQ@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <52372907.20709@rabbitmq.com>

Those are not necessarily errors.

They're logged by the JSON-RPC channel plugin. This plugin emulates 
sort-of-AMQP-ish messaging, implemented underneath by HTTP polling.

The timeouts occur when a browser goes away without sending a channel / 
connection close. Quite plausible.

> HTTP Channel started, timeout 2000

This means a channel has started with a 2000s timeout.

> HTTP Channel timed out, closing.

This means a timeout occurred.

Cheers, Simon

On 16/09/13 16:40, sagu prf wrote:
> Hello Team ,
>
>               I am getting following errors frequently , could you
> please advise me ?
>
> /var/log/rabbitmq$ tail -10o rabbit at linuxserv1 |grep time
> HTTP Channel timed out, closing.
> HTTP Channel timed out, closing.
> HTTP Channel timed out, closing.
> HTTP Channel started, timeout 2000
> HTTP Channel started, timeout 300
> HTTP Channel started, timeout 900
>
> RabbitMQ version 2.8.7 with Erlang R15B02
>
> Regards
> sagu
> _______________________________________________
> rabbitmq-discuss mailing list
> rabbitmq-discuss at lists.rabbitmq.com
> https://lists.rabbitmq.com/cgi-bin/mailman/listinfo/rabbitmq-discuss
>


-- 
Simon MacMullen
RabbitMQ, Pivotal

From mklishin at gopivotal.com  Mon Sep 16 16:52:58 2013
From: mklishin at gopivotal.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 2013 16:52:58 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] regarding HTTP Channel started Time out ,

In-Reply-To: <CAMK+tBipj2g+r=z3g3zJ46V+vg1CZAd9t4_iub=Y7_760mnJXQ@mail.gmail.com>
References: <CAMK+tBipj2g+r=z3g3zJ46V+vg1CZAd9t4_iub=Y7_760mnJXQ@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <EEE2DAD1-7A34-4634-BF28-D0BF302E3773@rabbitmq.com>


On sep 16, 2013, at 4:40 p.m., sagu prf <sagu.prf1 at gmail.com> wrote:

>            I am getting following errors frequently , could you
> please advise me ?
> 
> /var/log/rabbitmq$ tail -10o rabbit at linuxserv1 |grep time
> HTTP Channel timed out, closing.
> HTTP Channel timed out, closing.
> HTTP Channel timed out, closing.
> HTTP Channel started, timeout 2000
> HTTP Channel started, timeout 300
> HTTP Channel started, timeout 900

There was a thread about this message just a few days ago.

It's not really an error. It means that HTTP client (in case of JSON-RPC, a Web browser)
disconnected and its connection timed out.

It should be a warning since it's harmless.

MK

#!/usr/bin/env python
import pika

connection = pika.BlockingConnection(pika.ConnectionParameters(
            host='localhost'))
channel = connection.channel()


channel.queue_declare(queue='hello')

channel.basic_publish(exchange='',
            routing_key='hello',
            body='Hello World!')
print " [x] Sent 'Hello World!'"
connection.close()

From sbrockway at gmail.com  Mon Sep 16 16:11:16 2013
From: sbrockway at gmail.com (Sean Brockway)
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 2013 08:11:16 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Web admin interface - doesn't filter Connection
 nor Channels tabs by virtual host
Message-ID: <d368de6f-d178-4be6-b7b5-84be34b8096f@googlegroups.com>

Minor issue/defect.

The Virtual Host drop down box in the upper right of the page does *not *filter 
table rows to the selected virtual host on the following tabs:

   - Connection
   - Channels

The filtering *does *work on the Exchanges and Queues tab (and is very 
helpful).
There is a virtual host column on the Connection and Channels tab so it 
would seem like filtering would be available.  It would be helpful, 
especially for the Connetions tab to have the filtering feature.

We are using RabbitMQ v3.1.5
Browsing from Chrome v29

Recommend adding the support to filter on these two tabs, or 
hiding/disabling the filter drop down if filtering is not possible or not 
intended for these tabs.



-------------- next part --------------

URL: <http://lists.rabbitmq.com/pipermail/rabbitmq-discuss/attachments/20130916/927a36c2/attachment.htm>

From ben.hsu at criticalmedia.com  Mon Sep 16 17:15:48 2013
From: ben.hsu at criticalmedia.com (Ben Hsu)
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 2013 12:15:48 -0400
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] =?utf-8?q?_Re=3A__Proper_process_to_change_erl?=
 =?utf-8?q?ang_cookie=3F?=
In-Reply-To: <CAMcAHLVY2B-RFTnCLh12Fh28T=LRjheiSE5uQ3ELrQmeKCancg@mail.gmail.com>
References: <etPan.52338c92.22cc3dbb.22ad@heartoftheneutronstar.local>
	<CAMcAHLVY2B-RFTnCLh12Fh28T=LRjheiSE5uQ3ELrQmeKCancg@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <etPan.52372eb4.6b8b4567.4f32@heartoftheneutronstar.local>

Thank you Alvaro, turns out on my setup the rabbitmq user's home directory was /var/lib/rabbitmq, and I thought /var/lib/rabbitmq/.erlang.cookie was common to all users

--?
Ben Hsu
Sent with Airmail

On September 13, 2013 at 7:39:41 PM, Alvaro Videla (videlalvaro at gmail.com) wrote:

The Erlang cookie belongs to each particular user on your machines. The?cookie can be found on ~/.erlang.cookie and you need to have the same value there for every node in the cluster.

start_app stops the Rabbit application inside the Erlang VM but the VM has to be running for that to work.?

stop_app will stop the rabbit app, but not the Erlang VM

rabbitmq-server takes care of preparing the env parameters and starting the Erlang VM to then run RabbitMQ on it.

Regards,

Alvaro

On Friday, September 13, 2013, Ben Hsu wrote:
Hello all

I need to change the erlang cookie on my RabbitMQ server to get clustering working, and wish to know the correct procedure.

I tried doing this:

rabbitmqctl stop_app
vi /var/lib/rabbitmq/.erlang.cookie
rabbitmqctl start_app # this gave me an error message:?Error: unable to connect to node 'rabbit at ben-amqp-test4': nodedown

By trial and error, I found this worked:
pkill beam
pkill epmd
vi /var/lib/rabbitmq/.erlang.cookie
rabbitmq-server?
# now in a separate window, for some reason it didn't work with rabbitmq-server -detached
rabbitmqctl start_app

That seemed to work, but is ugly, and doesn't feel like the right way of doing it.

Also, what is the difference between "rabbitmqctl start_app" and "rabbitmq-server"?

Thanks in advance

--?
Ben Hsu
Sent with Airmail

Message-ID: <52373100.7040709@rabbitmq.com>

Hmm. That looks like some problem (in the server) encoding the response 
to connection.start-ok, i.e. connection.tune. Have you customised the 
frame_max or heartbeat setting in the rabbitmq.config file? Can you post 
your config?

Cheers, Simon

An HTML attachment was scrubbed...

From simon at rabbitmq.com  Mon Sep 16 17:56:19 2013
From: simon at rabbitmq.com (Simon MacMullen)
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 2013 17:56:19 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Change flow control params
In-Reply-To: <1a43d34d-6ea4-4dce-8cd9-bf44cfd4348c@googlegroups.com>
References: <1a43d34d-6ea4-4dce-8cd9-bf44cfd4348c@googlegroups.com>
Message-ID: <52373833.30609@rabbitmq.com>

On 15/09/13 11:05, Bruce Dou wrote:
> Any one changes -define(DEFAULT_CREDIT, {200, 50}). ?
> It seems the throughput changes when I modify these 2 param.

Does it change for the better or the worse? What change did you make?

When we developed the flow control feature we considered making this 
tunable, but there seemed to be a fairly broad plateau for the initial 
credit values with broadly similar performance, so we just picked values 
in the middle of that range and stuck with it. If you have a scenario 
where tuning this value does something useful I'd like to hear about it...

Cheers, Simon

-- 
Simon MacMullen
RabbitMQ, Pivotal

From matthias at rabbitmq.com  Mon Sep 16 18:26:45 2013
From: matthias at rabbitmq.com (Matthias Radestock)
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 2013 18:26:45 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] can not connect to rabbitmq because
	pika.exceptions.ProbableAuthenticationError
In-Reply-To: <CAD9nsJtfBphBMCvyBHQtZy5A-OrWbUo2ewx26YEn=2mm_20kpA@mail.gmail.com>

The other day I was wondering the same and I randomly changed the defaults
to this: {20000, 50} and it hurt performance badly, at least for the very
simple test I was running of "push as many small messages as possible".

-Alvaro


On Mon, Sep 16, 2013 at 9:56 AM, Simon MacMullen <simon at rabbitmq.com> wrote:

> On 15/09/13 11:05, Bruce Dou wrote:
>
>> Any one changes -define(DEFAULT_CREDIT, {200, 50}). ?
>> It seems the throughput changes when I modify these 2 param.
>>
>
> Does it change for the better or the worse? What change did you make?
>
> When we developed the flow control feature we considered making this
> tunable, but there seemed to be a fairly broad plateau for the initial
> credit values with broadly similar performance, so we just picked values in
> the middle of that range and stuck with it. If you have a scenario where
> tuning this value does something useful I'd like to hear about it...
>
> Cheers, Simon
>
> --
> Simon MacMullen
> RabbitMQ, Pivotal

From jhalterman at gmail.com  Tue Sep 17 01:13:34 2013
From: jhalterman at gmail.com (Jonathan Halterman)
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 2013 17:13:34 -0700
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Towards better handling of RabbitMQ
	connection/channel failures
Message-ID: <CA+es_-y=cPBnS2W-+k8Gp+XS32JjaRcYK438AeP9B4tpW3K2MQ@mail.gmail.com>

I've been experimenting with various sorts of RabbitMQ failures that result
in connections and channels being shutdown with the goal of being able to
re-establish connections, channels, and consumers whenever a failure
occurs. In particular, I've been forcing network partitions on a
pause_minority configured cluster with a client connected to what will
become the minority node, to see how things behave, and the results are a
bit inconsistent.

For a simple test, I created 2 connections and 6 channels then partitioned
the cluster. Within a minute or so the minority node (to which my client is
connected connected) shuts itself down. What happens next varies a bit
which each test run:

Outcome 1: Immediately the shutdown listeners for my 2 connections and all
6 channels are called.

Outcome 2: Immediately 2 of my 6 channels' shutdown listeners are called.
None of the connection shutdown listeners are called. After waiting a few
minutes I heal the partition and the shutdown listeners for the 2
connections and the remaining 4 channels are immediately called.

Outcome 3: Immediate 2 of my 6 channels' shutdown listeners are called.
None of the connection shutdown listeners are called. After about 30
seconds, with the cluster still partitioned, the shutdown listeners for the
2 connections and the remaining 4 channels are immediately called.

---

I'm interested to learn more about when and why certain shutdown listeners
might or might not be invoked so I can do a better job of re-establishing
resources after a failure. Any input is appreciated.

Cheers,
Jonathan
-------------- next part --------------

URL: <http://lists.rabbitmq.com/pipermail/rabbitmq-discuss/attachments/20130916/2ac6ddab/attachment.htm>

On Mon, Sep 16, 2013 at 8:51 AM, Simon MacMullen <simon at rabbitmq.com> wrote:
> Those are not necessarily errors.
>
> They're logged by the JSON-RPC channel plugin. This plugin emulates
> sort-of-AMQP-ish messaging, implemented underneath by HTTP polling.
>
> The timeouts occur when a browser goes away without sending a channel /
> connection close. Quite plausible.
>
>
>> HTTP Channel started, timeout 2000
>
>
> This means a channel has started with a 2000s timeout.
>
>
>> HTTP Channel timed out, closing.
>
>
> This means a timeout occurred.
>
> Cheers, Simon
>
>
> On 16/09/13 16:40, sagu prf wrote:
>>
>> Hello Team ,
>>
>>               I am getting following errors frequently , could you
>> please advise me ?
>>
>> /var/log/rabbitmq$ tail -10o rabbit at linuxserv1 |grep time
>> HTTP Channel timed out, closing.
>> HTTP Channel timed out, closing.
>> HTTP Channel timed out, closing.
>> HTTP Channel started, timeout 2000
>> HTTP Channel started, timeout 300
>> HTTP Channel started, timeout 900
>>
>> RabbitMQ version 2.8.7 with Erlang R15B02
>>
>> Regards
>> sagu

From michael at rabbitmq.com  Tue Sep 17 06:05:50 2013
From: michael at rabbitmq.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Tue, 17 Sep 2013 06:05:50 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Rabbitmq help
In-Reply-To: <CAMK+tBiJc2v4bdZo35F-qEz-MZ35AQ71Y-JKUtYHPVzWd4=62A@mail.gmail.com>
References: <CAMK+tBiJc2v4bdZo35F-qEz-MZ35AQ71Y-JKUtYHPVzWd4=62A@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <CA876EB0-5786-4F39-AB76-619A5044414B@rabbitmq.com>


On sep 17, 2013, at 5:00 a.m., sagu prf <sagu.prf1 at gmail.com> wrote:

> how this shovel act upon one DC failure /Network failure ?

Shovel is AP in CAP, it will try to reconnect and republish messages.

> 
> How i can bounce the service gracefully in this scenario ?

If you need replication with more than one point, consider federation or
perhaps a load balancer in front of Shovel.

> How to handle the issue  if any the Rabbitmq are overloaded ?

Below is a very generic advice without knowing any details about
your workload.

Add more nodes to the cluster (Shovel can replicate between clusters),
make some clients connect to the new node and use additional queues there.
More nodes will not help you if the issue is a single giant queue (queues are
not sharded: this may be implemented in a future version).

You can monitor queue lengths and message rates using HTTP API and
add more nodes to the cluster when you consider it overloaded.

MK

Hi there!
Now I have a problem that server RabbitMQ sometimes sends to me the RST
packets.
Scenario is as below:
1) I create about 10 consumers (declare exchanges, queues, make binds and
start consume)
2) Create producer (which use own connection and that use confirm extantion
with mandatory bit set on)
3) After that I delete all consumers (make unbind and close using channels
and connections)
4) try to send message from my producer... and amqp_basic_publish returns
error 9 (socket error)
and in WireShark i see that server send to me RST packet.

Do you have any idea what is the problem? And in that cases server can send
RST packets?

From tyger2007 at gmail.com  Tue Sep 17 07:52:56 2013
From: tyger2007 at gmail.com (Iyenemi Tyger)

Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] designing and developing a feed system with
	rabbitmq

Hello and hood day everyone ,
I am a huge fan of rabbitmq knowing that it can solve most of the enterprise computing challenges , however I have a couple of questions to ask pertaining social based design .I am completely new to this approach .
1) if I am to design a system like twitter for example , how do I map the users to rabbitmq so they can recieve instant feeds 
2) best approaches in using rabbitmq for such a system ,thanks .

From mklishin at gopivotal.com  Tue Sep 17 09:48:25 2013
From: mklishin at gopivotal.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Tue, 17 Sep 2013 09:48:25 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] rabbitmq queue  empty
In-Reply-To: <0f1e8812-76dc-44e4-9f84-b1fc7940b748@googlegroups.com>
References: <0f1e8812-76dc-44e4-9f84-b1fc7940b748@googlegroups.com>
Message-ID: <B0BFFDDA-BE51-4A1C-B43E-D73C3FA1D561@rabbitmq.com>

skrishna at aristanetworks.com:

> I have installed RabbitMQ for graylog2  server. Seems  everything looks fine.
> 
> Bu when  I  access  the rabbitmq portal  with the port  15672 ., I don't see  any  queue messages under message  ready, unacked and total colums  that  shows always empty  and  the parameters  is TTL and  the status columns is  IDLE always . I am not expert in rabbitmq . I just installed jsut becuase of graylog2 for queuing messages.
> I need  help on this. Pls suggest what could be the reason of this .

RabbitMQ supports multi-tenancy via vhosts (similar to Apache or Nginx vhosts).

Graylog2 probably uses its own vhost and by default the UI presents you the default
vhost (/). See the switcher in the top right corner:

https://www.monosnap.com/image/7aINJygDxDsomYVqwb9AvTw7s

and select the vhost you need. Note that you may need to log out and
log back in with a user that has access to the Graylog2 vhost.

MK

From mklishin at gopivotal.com  Tue Sep 17 09:50:47 2013
From: mklishin at gopivotal.com (Michael Klishin)
Date: Tue, 17 Sep 2013 09:50:47 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] designing and developing a feed system with
	rabbitmq
In-Reply-To: <58206204-61f7-47c1-9dab-ac4824854943@googlegroups.com>
References: <58206204-61f7-47c1-9dab-ac4824854943@googlegroups.com>
Message-ID: <8D004769-9801-4E8C-8649-DFA2C7B5BA9D@rabbitmq.com>

On sep 17, 2013, at 7:52 a.m., Iyenemi Tyger <tyger2007 at gmail.com> wrote:

> 1) if I am to design a system like twitter for example , how do I map the users to rabbitmq so they can recieve instant feeds 

RabbitMQ is good for inter-app communication but it's not really a database.

You can use one queue or one queue per user but in the end there has to be an app (or multiple apps) that consumes those messages and stores them somewhere.

Activity collection is certainly a very common use case, see [1] and [2] [3].

1. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DlNS5Ohf6w
2. http://shelby.tv/video/vimeo/66303052/nosql-matters-cologne-2013-day2-track1-03-sebastian-roebke-stefan-kaes
3. http://2013.nosql-matters.org/cgn/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/2013-04-27-Triple-R-NoSQLMatters2013-Compact.pdf

As a general advice, you can start with 1 queue and once that queue gets congested, move to
multiple queues (e.g. using consistent hashing exchange) and more consumer apps.

MK

From emile at rabbitmq.com  Tue Sep 17 09:56:50 2013
From: emile at rabbitmq.com (Emile Joubert)
Date: Tue, 17 Sep 2013 09:56:50 +0100
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] Sometimes RabbitMQ sends RST packets
In-Reply-To: <1379405333380-29701.post@n5.nabble.com>
References: <1379405333380-29701.post@n5.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <52381952.1080908@rabbitmq.com>


Hi,

On 17/09/13 09:08, Haster wrote:

> Do you have any idea what is the problem? And in that cases server can send
> RST packets? 

If the broker was responsible for forcing the connection to close then
the reason will be in the logfile. Check in the regular and sasl logfiles.

If the TCP connection is mediated by an intelligent network device then
that intermediary could be responsible for the RST. Try to rule that out
if it is a possibility.



-Emile




From Michal.Skorepa at Honeywell.com  Tue Sep 17 10:02:32 2013
From: Michal.Skorepa at Honeywell.com (Skorepa, Michal)
Date: Tue, 17 Sep 2013 09:02:32 +0000
Subject: [rabbitmq-discuss] RabbitMQ - Erlang AMQP client - mutual SSL
	authentication problem
Message-ID: <ABBDC9D7002EB54AB98BA60DA16D269333FEA9CD@FR44EX3003.global.ds.honeywell.com>

Hello,

I have a problem with establishing SSL connections between Erlang AMQP client (v. 3.0.2) and RabbitMQ server (v. 3.1.3). I need to use mutual authentication, i.e. I need to authenticate the server to the client with the server certificate as well as the client to the server with the client certificate. Authenticating the server to the client works fine (ssl_fail_if_no_peer_cert set to "true" at the client and to "false" at the server), but I am not able to make the client-to-servet authentication work ("true at both sides").

My SSL configs are the following:
RabbitMQ:
---------
{rabbit, [
        {ssl_listeners, [5677]},
        {ssl_options, [ {cacertfile, "/etc/ssl/xxx/ca_cert.pem"},
                                        {certfile, "/etc/ssl/xxx/cert.pem"},
                                        {keyfile, "/etc/ssl/xxx/key.pem"},
                                        {fail_if_no_peer_cert, true},
                                        {verify, verify_peer}
                ]
        }
        ]
},

Client:
--------
{port, 5677},
{ssl_cert_ca, "/etc/ssl/xxx/swim-ca_cert.pem"},
{ssl_cert, "/etc/ssl/xxx/cert.pem"},
{ssl_key, "/etc/ssl/xxx/key.pem"},
{ssl_verify, verify_peer},
{ssl_fail_if_no_peer_cert, true},
{username, <<"aaa">>},
{password, <<"aaa">>},
-----------------

I tried everyting that was suggested on the troubleshooting website (http://www.rabbitmq.com/troubleshooting-ssl.html) - check SSL support in Erlang, check the client and server certificates using OpenSSL, check broker listenning on SSL port, attempt SSL connection to broker using OpenSSL, validate client connections with stunnel.. I did not get any errors! I even tried to connect with the Erlang AMQP client to the OpenSSL server - this also worked! (I just got AMQP connection setup timeout after the SSL connection setup - which is not suprprising)

The error I am getting on the client side is:
---------------------------------------------------
{error, esslconnect}

The broker log says:
-------------------------
=ERROR REPORT==== 17-Sep-2013::10:39:40 ===
error on AMQP connection <0.9012.1>: {ssl_upgrade_error,esslaccept} (unknown POSIX error)

=INFO REPORT==== 17-Sep-2013::10:39:40 ===
accepting AMQP connection <0.9027.1> (xxx.xxx.138.17:56035 -> xxx.xxx.0.21:5677)

=ERROR REPORT==== 17-Sep-2013::10:39:40 ===
SSL: certify: ssl_connection.erl:496:Fatal error: handshake failure
---------------------------


Do you have any idea what could be wrong and how to fix it?

Thank you for any thaughts!
Michal

http://blog.rubyrabbitmq.info/blog/2013/09/17/rabbitmq-http-api-client-0-dot-4-0-is-released/
